contentrichtext.text: {{Expand French|date=March 2012|Maurice André}} [[File:Maurice André (1969).jpg|thumb|upright|Maurice André (1969)]] '''Maurice André''' (May 21, 1933{{spaced ndash}}February 25, 2012) was a French [[trumpeter]], active in the [[European classical music|classical music]] field. ==Biography== André was born in [[Alès]] in the [[Cévennes]], into a mining family. His father was an amateur musician. André studied trumpet with a friend of his father's, who suggested that André be sent to the [[music school|conservatory]]. In order to gain free admission to the conservatory, he joined a [[military band]]. After only six months at the conservatory, he won his first prize. At the conservatory, André's professor beat him out of frustration and told him to return when he could excel in his playing. A few weeks later, he returned to play all fourteen [[Étude|etudes]] found in the back of the [[Jean-Baptiste Arban|Arban]]'s [[Arban method|book]] without a single mistake.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Steven Chenette | title="It's My Greatest Joy" : An Interview with Maurice Andre | journal=International Trumpet Guild Journal| year=2001 | volume=30 | pages=08–19}}</ref> Maurice André won the [[Geneva International Music Competition]] in 1955 and the [[ARD International Music Competition]] in [[Munich]] in 1963. He was made an honorary member of the Delta chapter of [[Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia]] at Ithaca College in New York in 1970. André rose to international prominence in the 1960s and 1970s with a large series of recordings of [[Baroque]] works on [[piccolo trumpet]] for [[Erato Records|Erato]] and other labels. Not content to limit himself to the standard Baroque trumpet repertoire, André also performed many [[transcription (music)|transcriptions]] of works for oboe, flute, and even voice and string instruments. These recordings were (and remain) very popular, and were a strong component of the rebirth of interest in Baroque music in the 1960s. André had over 300 [[Sound recording|audio]] recordings to his name, from the mid-1950s to his death. He had three children: Lionel (1959-1988),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trumpetguild.org/pdf/2012journal/AndreLaplaceFr.pdf | title = Obituary by Michel Laplace| accessdate = 2013-05-09}}</ref> trumpeter and music teacher, Nicolas, who plays the trumpet; and Béatrice, who plays the oboe. All three performed with their father in concert. He also made several recordings with his brother Raymond (b. 1941).<ref>{{cite web | url = http://abel.hive.no/trompet/andre/raymond/ | title = Raymond André | accessdate = 2013-05-09}}</ref> One of André's students, [[Guy Touvron]] wrote a biography on him entitled ''Maurice André: Une trompette pour la renommée'' (Maurice André: A Trumpet for Fame), which was published in 2003.<ref>{{cite web | url = {{Allmusic|class=artist|id=q57185|pure_url=yes}} | title = Guy Touvron | work = [[Allmusic]] | last = Cummings | first = Robert | accessdate = 2010-12-15}}</ref> André spent the last few years of his life in retirement in the southern part of France. He died at the age of 78 in a hospital in [[Bayonne]] on February 25, 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17173246 |title=Trumpet player Maurice Andre dies aged 78 |author=BBC News |date=26 February 2012 |accessdate=26 February 2012}}</ref> He is buried in the cemetery of the village of [[Saint-André-Capcèze]] (in the [[Lozère]]). ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.maurice-andre.com Maurice André] website, part of the French Ministry of Culture's portal (French/English) *[http://abel.hive.no/trumpet/andre/ Webpage with rich information about Maurice André] *[http://www.frantisekslama.com/maurice-andre-1933-2012 Maurice André and Prague].
